reviewText: Cats Don't Dance / B000069I0HA cute and whimsical musical with a surprisingly deep subtext and a unique sound, "Cats Don't Dance" will please both young children and adults.When young tom Danny moves to Hollywood with big dreams, he is crushed to learn that animals are only allowed to feature in support roles, never as headliners. The discrimination subtext is obvious, but not heavy-handed. As a musical, "Cats Don't Dance" features the usual assortment of lovely, ear-catching tunes, but the artists are particularly gifted and the sounds here are - true to the underlying message - ones you won't hear in most other children's' musicals, including the rich, bluesy depth of Natalie Cole that simply must be heard to be believed.As a fun and meaningful musical, "Cats Don't Dance" is definitely worth checking out. There is some religious imagery (Danny is cast as a cat on a big "Noah's Ark" film that offers many animal parts), but the imagery is sensitive to the source, as the movie explores the value of eschewing hypocrisy.~ Ana Mardoll
Title: N/A

reviewText: I've been waiting for five years for this to come out on DVD because I know if I buy it on VHS I'll just have to buy more copies after I wear the first one out. This is one of the best animated movies of all times. It's an adorable cartoon without the saccharine overdose that many of them have. The hero is the adorable Danny, who dreams of becoming a movie star. The backup cast is just as enchanting, and are a little more jaded than the average cartoon character. The pacing is almost like speed, and it will sweep you up and hold you until the very end. If you want something deep, buy The Lion King. If you want something fun that will make you feel good, buy Cats Don't Dance. You won't be disappointed.

reviewText: Cats Don't Dance is a wonderful story about a simple cat from small-town nowhere, looking to make it big in Hollywood, in the late thirties. Naive as he is, he thinks it should only take him a week until he gets his first big part. But that was before he met Darla, a child-star similar to Shirley Temple, but with a much worse temper - and to top it off, she hates animals. And apparently, so does Hollywood. In Hollywood, Cats don't dance, or sing, or act; they meow, and that's it. Danny attempts to beat the odds, and become a big star. This movie is also filled will wonderful musical numbers reminiscent of the jazz age. This is a movie for adults and kids alike, but it is especially for those who enjoy accomplishing the impossible, and for those with a dream they won't deny
summary: A simple story for everyone who has a dream
Title: N/A

reviewText: The animation is both good an distinctive, the characters are clever, the songs are nice. The story is just a wee bit trite, but that's a Hollywood musical for you, isn't it?I liked this movie. I saw it in the theatre, and then bought it on tape as soon as it came out. Now I'm buying it on DVD. So why didn't I give it five stars?Basically, I'm a grouch. This movie takes a complex historical issue (the treatment of minorities, especially blacks, by Hollywood) and trivializes it. Yes, in the heydays of the Studio System in Hollywood there was a color line. For that matter there still is (in Liberal Hollywood, no less), although it isn't as strong. Nevertheless there were exceptions almost from the first, and also a thriving (if somewhat insulting, by today's standards)All Black film sub-industry. The situation decpicted in this movie never existed, as such. By the same token the discrimination didn't end suddenly either, as it does in this film. Lastly, the obvious model for the villianous Darla Dimple (Shirley Temple) was a very nice (if somewhat mawkish) little girl. People liked working with her. They've said so, often. The monstrous child star idea is kind of clever, and since Ms. Temple is the only one from that era that anyone will remember I guess Darla had to be patterned somewhat on her. I don't think it's quite fair to Ms. Temple, but I doubt she would mind if she knew. She was bigger than that.I only bring this up because I'm just a little tired of preachy films. I don't mind films with a message; I love PRINCESS MONONOKE. I simply object to the raising and knocking down of straw men. It gets old. It gets old fast.OK, rant over. Please note that despite my annoyace over its political aspects I liked this film enough to pay for it three times (Ticket, Tape, and DVD). If simplistic political messages annoy you you might want to try to rent this baby before you buy. Otherwise it's a Hollywood Musical; not at the level of  SINGING IN THE RAIN, but one heck of a lot better than XANADU. Better than average, in fact. Give it a try.
summary: It isn't Beauty and the Beast- but so what?

reviewText: Cat's Don't Dance is probably the most brilliant, heart-warming, outrageous animated film I've ever seen. While it may have not been a box office success in 1997, the film has been praised by critics and fans alike, featuring the brilliant voice talents of Scott Bakula (Star Trek: Enterprise) and Jasmine Guy (A Different World), and deserves the title of animated cult classic. I've instantly fell in love with this film, the characters, the animation, and the songs (especially Nothing's Gonna Stop Us Now) and my favorite characters are Danny, Sawyer, (the two of them make a wonderful couple.) and Pudge. My only complaint, I wish it was 10-15 minutes longer. Anyway, it's a wonderful movie and it changed my life. I highly HIGHLY reccommend it to anyone who love animated musicals and tributes to the Golden Age of Animation.

reviewText: When this film released in 1997, nobody paid attention to it, because Disney's Hercules was the animated feature film everyone assumed to be better.  Many animators would prefer Cats Don't Dance over Hercules, why?  It is a tap dancing musical that really plays with the art of animation.  The movie is directed by Mark Dindal (Emperor's New Groove) and the choreography is by the famous broadway dancing veteran Gene Kelley!  It is also the last film involves Gene Kelley.  Overall, the animation is wonderful, loveable characters, and unforgettable songs.  This is a movie for all ages of animation or musical fan.
summary: Superb!  A musical that would make Disney cry.

reviewText: This is a delightful film, no matter what your age is. The animation is spirited and brilliantly executed, the characters are a joy, especially Darla Dimple: a cross between Shirley Temple and a hysterical "Mommy Dearest" Joan Crawford, and the story is engaging.  The color styling is glorious.The songs are just fine, and wonderfully sung.  All these wonderful things were combined into a widescreen film that pulls the viewer in to a magical, musical world of beauty and humor.  Dvds were created to convey just this type of  magnificence to the television screen.In what has got to be one of the goofiest, bone-headed lapses of logic EVER, this dvd does NOT feature the widescreen version. Instead, we get a full-screen movie, with characters on the screen's edge (or not at all).  Still, it's better than nothing. If it were widescreen, I'd give it 5 stars. (I give the original movie 10 stars).If this movie comes out on widescreen on Blue-Ray disc, I'll definitely get it. If and when.

Title: N/A

reviewText: It's kind of sad that a lot of the time, no one pays any attention to animated movies that aren't from Disney (well, now it's more like Disney, Pixar and DreamWorks). Warner Bros. has proven the quality of its animation in the past, so it comes as no surprise their animated films also tend to be amazing. This one's no exception.The story itself is quite interesting - certainly never anything I've seen done in another film. It focuses mostly on animal actors in Hollywood and how they never get any good roles. Well, that and how it affects a guy from a small town with big dreams of becoming a star. It's so cool to see how this sort of story was portrayed using animals rather than people. As far as the characters, all so unique: the sassy female cat whose dreams of stardom were crushed by reality, the crotchety old lady fish and old man goat, the constantly anxious turtle who takes fortune cookie messages to heart, the overly cheery hippo lady, the veteran elephant whose working a lousy movie job while perfecting his real talents in secret...and, of course, there's Darla. I absolutely love how she is portrayed - sweet, perfect, angelic little child actress with cute blonde locks and a lovable smile. Yeah, on camera. Behind the scenes, she is a demon-spawn.One character I was not crazy over was Danny, the main character. Don't get me wrong, he's a fun personality and he's not out of place or anything. It's just I have seen that same character before and it's just kind of old-hat. On the other hand, I don't think any other type of character would have fit into his role, so it was kind of a necessary evil, I guess. The story is, of course, not all smiles and rainbows. Danny learns the hard way that he has unrealistic dreams, but manages to get his confidence back just in time to wrangle his animal friends together for one mind-blowing performance. It's got many elements all rolled into a single plot - comedy, adventure, singing, a bit of romance, even a fight scene on a giant balloon.I saw this movie when I was about 10 and even as an adult, it's still one of my favorite animated films. Go pound sand, Disney.

reviewText: Cats Don't dance is a fresh take on an old story.  Trying to make it big in Hollywood.  Except instead of people being the stars and trying to make it big, animals are the ones trying to become stars.  Danny, played by Scott Bakula, is a cat from a small town in Indiana who dreams of seeing is name in lights.  But Danny gets a rued awakening when he realizes that they're only looking for talented people in Hollywood.  He meets Sawyer, played by Jasmine Guy, a beautiful cat who has given up on her dreams of stardom.  Danny also meets Darla Dimple, the Shirley Temple from hell.  Darla Dimple is a conniving, manipulative brat who tries to kill Danny and his friends.  But Danny and friends get the last laugh when they finally get to perform on stage and blow the roof the building..literally.  My favorite scene is right after they finish performing and one guy in the audience is so blown away by their performance that his teeth crack and fall out.  This is a very good movie.  It will keep you singing and dancing the whole time.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Danny, a cat in a straw boater, leaves Kokomo to take Hollywood by storm. He steps off the bus in Hollywood and starts singing, "Since I was a little kitten, I had a dream. My name in lights, Danny the song and dance cat."His first stop is the office of Farley Wink - Animal Actors Agency, and amazingly, he immediately lands the part of "Cat" in Mammoth Pictures' next vehicle for child star Darla Dimples, the singingest dancingest cutest little moppet to ever grace the silver screen. The next day, Danny shows up all excited and is given his script: "Cat #1: MEOW!". This can't be right, he thinks, maybe I can embellish it. But when he does, he is corrected by Darla's Kong-like butler, Max, whose sobriquet should be Max the Menace. Sawyer, the lovely lady cat, who's given up her Hollywood dreams to become Wink's secretary, tells the crestfallen Danny, "Listen Tiger! This town has rules. Around here, cats say Meow."Danny refuses to give up, though, and thinks up a scheme to showcase all the animal talents to J.B. Mammoth, studio head. Unfortunately, he enlists the help of Darla Dimple, being possibly the last person in Hollywood to realize that Darla is no darling, she's a tyrant, and she hates animals.No year is given for the action in the 1997 "Cats Don't Dance", but it's the era of movie moguls and the star system. Danny feels like a young Donald O'Connor and, together with the fashions shown, I'd guess it's the 40's. A lot of the songs have a swing feel to them, and there's a couple of real toe-tapping jazzy numbers.Scott Bakula plays Danny. Jasmine Guy is the voice of Sawyer. And the wonderful voice of Natalie Cole sings Sawyer's songs. Songs are composed by Randy Newman, who's done right by other animated features.DVD Special Features:1.  Cast & Crew. A one-page listing of primary players.2.  "Hooray For Hollywood". This is a six-part quiz about what happens in the movie. Use your remote control to select your answers. It's not as easy as it looks.3.  "Sawyer's Songbook"  Seven songs from the movie are separated, so you can watch/listen to them by themselves.4.  Theatrical trailer for "Cats Don'e Dance"5.  Trailers for the DVD issues of "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory" and "Wizard of Oz".6.  CD ROM material. Insert the DVD in your computer. After you install interactualPlayer 2.0, you can play three mini-games with "Cats Don't Dance" themes.This is an enjoyable family movie with a couple excellent songs. In particular, "Nothing's Gonna Stop Us Now" is a gem.
summary: Fun Family Animated Musical - the DVD Extras are slim

reviewText: "Cats Don't Dance" really took me by surprise. What a clever idea, flawlessly executed! If you enjoy musicals of the 40s and 50s, and if you enjoy bold, fast-paced animation, then this is the movie for you. Set in the 1940s, a naive but talented cat moves from the Mid-West to Hollywood, hoping to sing and dance his way to the top. His hopes are quickly obstructed by the Hollywood machine, which is dominated by Darla Dimple - a hilarious Shirley Temple parody. The villainous Dimple finally gets what she deserves, as does the hopeful Danny the cat. A true gift from Warner Brothers to animated film lovers and their children. The movie really clicks with my kids.

reviewText: I never would have known this movie existed were it not for the Nostalgia Critic, who cited this as one of the movies he enjoyed too much to nitpick.  I was able to secure a copy via our library's inter-library loan system, and convinced my family -- all avid Disney and Pixar buffs -- to sit down and watch it with me.  And we all found ourselves laughing, sympathizing with the characters, and even dancing in our seats a bit with the music.  In short, we loved it, and couldn't believe we'd never heard of it before."Cats Don't Dance" is the story of Danny, a small-town cat who in the 1930s travels to Hollywood to fulfill his dream of being a movie star.  He arrives in Tinseltown with wide eyes and grand dreams... only to learn that animals in Hollywood are without exception passed over for leading roles and relegated to stereotypical animal roles in movies.  Undaunted, Danny enlists the help of a motley crew -- an adorable penguin, an optimistic hippo, a musically inclined elephant, a cynical fish, a cowardly turtle, a cantankerous goat, and the more down-to-earth female cat Sawyer -- in an effort to break into the business.  But someone's out to shoot down Danny's dreams... animal-hating child star Darla Dimple, who will stop at nothing to ensure a cat doesn't steal her spotlight.While not as groundbreaking or "deep" as a Pixar film, "Cats Don't Dance" has everything that makes cartoons fun -- catchy music, colorful and smooth animation, quirky characters (except for Danny, who comes off as fairly bland in comparison), an over-the-top villianess, and slapstic humor aplenty.  It's not an Oscar contender, but it doesn't need to be.  It knows just what it is -- a fun and fluffy family film with a warm heart -- and doesn't try to pretend otherwise.  In short, it's an underrated little gem that deserves at least one viewing.

reviewText: Anyone who tries to break into Hollywood today will recognize this golden age portrait of the musical era.  The great musical era personified by the late Howard Keel.  Keel could easily have been the inspiration for the feline hero Danny, who, a la Gene Kelly, sweeps the female, serious actress Sawyer, off her feet, which she lands on, dancing up a storm.  The animals of Tinseltown are treated...well, just like any other actors in the pecking order.  And Miss Darla Dimple is a wicked satire on the producer/child star from hell.
summary: A funny sendup of the biz

reviewText: This film received favorable reviews from critics and genuinely is an unrealized gem; however, its lack of popularity and status as a box office failure have rendered it almost entirely forgotten. However, I haven't a clue as to WHY this little film did not go on to become a cultural phenomenon, and in fact believe that it is DEFINITELY more worthy of such fame than a few things that actually DID go on to become examples of popular cultural phenomena. It is set in a world in which anthropomorphic animals and humans co-exist, but the animals seldom receive the starring roles in movies that they desire. It all changes when a charming cat named Danny decides to stand up for the animal actors, much to the infuriation of a child star named Darla Dimple. The musical numbers are superb and catchy without being cheesy, and the characters are laughable if they are intended to be so and loveable if they are intended to appear loveable. However, the musical numbers may just, in fact, be the highlight of the entire film, particularly those performed by Darla Dimple herself. If you agree that such a film is certainly worthy of more praise than it wound up receiving, you must purchase it AS SOON AS POSSIBLE. You really are missing out if you have not watched it already.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Contrary to Mr. Maltin's opinion, this movie isn't dreary. It's bright, clever, well animated, and well executed. Plus, it's funny, really funny. Not only that, you'll be snapping your fingers while watching this movie in  no time flat. The characters are completely unforgettable. These are full  toons we're talking about, like Bugs Bunny and Road Runner. This movie also  doesn't try to be something it's not. It's not a grand adventure, and it's  not a morality play. Many animated movies that tried to do one or the other  or both have failed. This movie masks its message behind a just-have-fun  attitude. Okay, so this isn't The Iron Giant or Bambi or what have you, but  it's still fun all the same. Listen to the cover for once. It is the  funniest animated movie since Aladdin. Well, one of the funniest now.

reviewText: This is lots of fun to watch. It has a lot of big names in it and the music is really good (How that gal can hold that note for so long in "Sing It Loud" is beyond me.). Adults will appreciate the parody of many famous 30's stars. The musical numbers are in the tradition of Busby Berkley and the story even holds together really well. Being a cartoon, there are things that can be done which are physically impossible in the real world, which makes the move that much more fun. Put on your toe-tapping shoes and sit back for a fun hour and a half ride. Even if your kids have moved out, you'll enjoy this if you like musicals.
summary: A kids movie but also for grownups.

reviewText: I like this movie a lot.  It's got great characters, pretty good songs, and Lovely (in my opinion) animation.  There are just some things about it that killed the box office.First, the introductions to all the songs with Danny are really quite hideous.  After that, the songs are good, but the bad intros just spoil it.  Not to mention the--hmmmm--INTERSESTING choice of music on the opening credits.  What fathomable reason is there for putting an annoying pop song over the opening credits of a 30'S-STYLE ANIMATED MUSICAL?  The opening credits themselves are pretty neat--roadsigns and sights with names on them--but the pop song just kills it.Second, it has some parts specifically for kids, and some parts specifically for grown-ups, making the movie end up for neither to sit through.Also, the story doesn't QUITE stand up to scrutiny--why would Darla choose NOW to try to get rid of the animals?  Just because Danny showed up?  What did HE have that was so special? The animals had all tried the audition thing before, why would it work now?  And why would Darla worry?  She CAN sing and dance!  If they had made it so that she didn't actually have talent, THAT would have made a better story point, but they'd still need to fix some things.In short: lovely little movie, it just needs a few bugs worked out.  The designs, characters, and coreography (by Gene Kelly-- the star of "Singin' in the Rain") are to die for.  Yeah, the story could make more sense, but watch it for the animation and design and overall charm, if nothing else. (Still have doubts? Look at it this way: The director went on to do "The Emperor's New Groove", so this can't be THAT bad!)
Title: N/A

reviewText: CATS DON'T DANCE is a toe-tapping, unusual little animated film featuring a host of musically inclined animals, headed by the stubborn and determined cat of the title.  As voiced by Scott Bakula, the cat is determined to make it big in Hollywood, where animals aren't supposed to be stars.  His nemesis turns out to be Darla Dimple, a Shirley Temple rip-off, who is really more demon than child.  Darla and her bodyguard Max are actually the funniest characters in the movie and they steal any scene they're in.  With a so-so score by Oscar winner Randy Newman, CATS DON'T DANCE is an entertaining movie, with some bouncy musical numbers and the message that quitters never win.

reviewText: For those who are complaining this film only had the full-screen treatment on DVD, the FS version of the film is NOT a pan & scan, but rather an open-matte transfer from the original camera negative (this film was "shot" in 1.37:1 for Home video/TV and "matted" for 1.85 theatrical because the animator likely hates pan & scamming his/her material). To prove this, I got a 1.78:1 16:9 screen capture off a HUB broadcast, and compared it to the FF DVD. The latter loses 20% vertically and gains about 5% horizontally, while the former preserves the height of the 1.37:1 ratio, but shaves a bit of the sides.For those who still crave the Widescreen version, the Fox R2 UK DVD and the NSTC Laserdisc present it in the original theatrical ratio.  For those a still craving it on DVD in NSTC R1, there is an earlier 1999 DVD with the "Warner Bros Family Entertainment" banner that has the WS version on one side, FF on the other (Warning: the WS version IS NOT 16:9 ENHANCED and both transfers suffer from interlace twittering).  This release is VERY VERY VERY VERY hard to find!! Ebay listings for it have reached upwards of $220 for good copies and Amazon lists this for $79.99, but will sell you the 2002 and/or 2009 releases that are FF only (unless you get it from a 3rd party seller THAT KNOWS EXACTLY WHAT HE HAS).
summary: Decent film, "Full-screen" release, but is not what you think it is

reviewText: Honestly, even though this is a kid's movie, no child under twelve could appreciate the sardonic humor and brilliant execution of Cats Don't Dance. The biting satire of Hollywood is spot on, and the duplicitous Darla Dimple is uproariously well done. I love this movie. No matter how many times I see it, no matter what age, I always laugh. The one liners will amuse you and your friends for years after watching. The music is catchy too. It gets stuck in your head because the songs are top notch.
summary: Can a movie be more amazing!?

reviewText: I loved this movie when it was released in theaters. I loved it when it was released on Laserdisc (widescreen). I was very excited about the DVD release, hoping for a widescreen edition and maybe some extras. Full screen and bare bones is what we got. What a HUGE disappointment. I'll keep watching my widescreen Laserdisc until this movie gets the DVD or blu-ray release it deserves. But, I'm not holding my breath.

reviewText: It may not be a classic but "Cats Don't Dance" is a fun time killer.PLOT - It's the 1930s and no animal has been able to reach the star status of their human counterparts: Clark Gable, Cary Grant, Joan Crawford, etc. The only thing animals are wanted for is to say animal lines and do stereotypical animal things.Then from Kokomo, Indiana comes the naive, humble but ambitious Danny (Scott Bakula, throwing out a voice that is decades younger than he actually is and doing his own singing), a fast tapping tap dancer who dreams of being the cat version of Gene Kelly or Bing Crosby, so he comes to Hollywood to seek his fortune, only to find a town full of crushed souls and broken dreams. He also runs afoul of Darla Dimple (speaking voice Ashley Peldon, singing voice Lindsay Ridgeway), a demented, narcissistic child star who is basically an evil version of Shirley Temple but pretends to be the sweet little girl image that the public has of her, which includes loving animals when she really despises them, when he tries to upstage her during the filming of "Little Ark Angel". Did I mention Darla's giant man-servant/hit man/enforcer Max? Despite the set backs, Danny becomes determined to lead an animal revolt that will lead his fellow animal performers to stardom.Along the way, Danny befriends Pudge, a chubby little penguin just trying to get by, Cranston the crotchety goat (voice of Hal Holbrook), Frances the Marlene Dietrich style fish (voiced by the late Betty Lou Gerson, who also voiced Cruella Deville in the original 101 Dalmations), a warm hearted hippo woman named Tillie (voice of Kathy Najimy), TW Turtle (the late Don Knotts), the mentor figure Woolie the Mammoth (John Rhys-Davies), and of course, the sassy, cynical love interest Sawyer (spoken by Jasmine Guy, sung by Natalie Cole).All of them had dreams of being song & dance stars, as Woolie explains to Danny. Tillie wanted to sing and dance, Cranston and Frances were a dancing duet, TW had dramatic pirate of penzance in his past, while Woolie himself is actually a very skilled piano player and had hopes of writing music for the movies, but instead he became the Mammoth Studios mascot, putting on giant tusks and blowing his snout at the beginning of every Mammoth Studio picture, much like the roaring lion at the beginning of the MGM films (he probably lucked out better than the others did in that respect). We even learn that Sawyer too once dreamed of song & dance stardom, as she was quite a dancer herself and had what Woolie called "the voice of an angel" (though it's really more along the lines of Diana Ross); Woolie even thought that Sawyer would be the one to break through. Woolie instructs Danny that Hollywood will never appreciate animal actors enough to give them their time in the spotlight, but this only strengthens Danny's resolve and, the next day, Danny gets Woolie and Pudge to join him in rallying the other animals together and inspiring them to fight for their right to be stars; he even gets Sawyer in on the back alley boogie, luring her into a pleasant fantasy where she gets to show off her dance moves, but she quickly breaks loose from it and tells Danny that it'll never happen.What Danny doesn't know is that Darla is on to him and, fearing that Danny and his animal cohorts might threaten her stardom, she tricks Danny into believing that she'll help him and lets him use her sound stage to from "Little Ark Angel" to perform for studio head L.B. Mammoth (voice of George Kennedy). Danny then rallies his fellow animals together, taking Darla's advice to make it "big & loud", and even gets Sawyer in on the act, still unaware of Darla's plot to destroy him. Darla KO's Pudge and then plays havoc with the special effects on the sound stage, resulting in a giant water mass spill out that engulfs both LB and the director Flanigan, leads to much mayhem on the studio lot and a fight between Sawyer & Danny. When the animals are all unceremoniously fired, Darla shows up to add insult to injury, exposing that she was the one who gave Danny use of the sound stage, making him even less popular with his already angry cohorts. Even Woolie tells Danny to just go home. The next night while Cranston, Frances, TW and Tillie lament their woes and blame Danny for ruining their already miserable careers, Sawyer takes to the rainy streets and sings of her own disillusionment with the industry and her confused feelings for Danny, which Tillie overhears and encourages her to go catch Danny before he leaves town. Danny, depressed and dejected over the calamity he has brought unto himself and his friends, miserably boards a bus back for Kokomo, leaving behind his hat for Sawyer to find and his list for how he would succeed, which leaves Sawyer tearful, heart broken and alone.But naturally Danny's resolve kicks back in and, with help from Pudge, he makes a desperate last ditch effort to break the barrier, by bringing his closest friends to the premiere of Darla Dimple's new film, where they sing and dance their hearts out, wowing the audience, and exposing Darla for the evil little thing that she is and destroying her career. From there Woolie, Tillie, TW, Pudge, Frances, Cranston, and of course, Sawyer & Danny, become big stars, headlining animal versions of "Superman", "Batman & Robin", "Grumpy Old Men", "The Mask", "Beetle Juice", "The Witches of Eastwick", and "Singing In The Rain", among others.Surprisingly entertaining due to its unabashed good naturedness and breezy songs. Above average animation too.
Title: N/A

reviewText: "SINCE I WAS A LITTLE KITTEN I HAD A DREAM, MY NAME IN LIGHTS, DANNY THE SONG AND DANCE CAT...GOT ON A BUS AND CAME TO THE TOWN WHERE DREAMS CAN COME TRUE...IT'S GOING TO HAPPEN FOR ME, IT COULD HAPPEN TO YOU" ...Danny a Lanky Energetic Audacious red hair Cat with a lot of Spunk and Big Dreams of Stardom from Kokomo Ind. on his way to Hollywood fast getting an Agent at "Farley Wink Animal Actors Agency" and getting his first Part in a Movie...well, one line "MEOW" but soon he realizes they're problems to tackle, one is descrimination, Not a Big demand for Singing and Dancing AnimalsAfter learning of all the broken dreams from other Animal Actors and feeling down and out, Danny almost returns home, he's persuaded by a Beautiful Classy Lady Cat named Tilly, so he decides to give it another try ..."I'VE GOT RHYTHM IN MY FEET, I'VE GOT RHYTHM IN MY HEART AND SOUL ...I'VE GOT RHYTHM HOT AND SWEET SOMETIMES RHYTHM MAKES ME LOOSE CONTROL"...Danny Tilly and a group of enthusiastic newfound Animal friends from the Talent Agency deciding to Show Tinsel-Town, that dreams can really come true, in a Big Comedy Musical from Warners Bros"CATS DON'T DANCE" a Full-lenth Animated Feature Film, reminiscing of the 1940's MGM Musicals A Rags-to-riches story of a deternmine Cat and his talented buddy friends. Colorful and Stylized Model Designs, fast paced snappy full Animation, with quick takes, typical of Warner Bros, very Vibrant Backgrounds, Great Music Songs by Randy Newman and Natalie Cole, a Terrific Fun Experience I really enjoyded and I'm sure you will too! ..."I'VE SEEN THEM COME AND SEEN THEM GO THERE"S ONE THING THAT I KNOW...YOU'VE GOT TO GIVE PEOPLE WHAT THEY WANT...OR YOU'LL WIND UP BACK IN KOKOMO!"...Thank You D.D.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I kinda bought this on a whim and faintly remembered seeing it years ago. Got it on amazon.com really cheap and I'll say...I'd gladly pay TWICE as much to own it! The mive is a bit short, but if you are looking for a good animated movie, look no further! The story is about anthropomorphic beings in the 1930's who are trying to break into Hollywood. Danny, a sharp witted funny cat, Sawyer, a dancing, singing feline, and an entire host of others are trying to break into Hollywood and show that animated cartoons can be just as big as real people (and some animated films are actually BETTER).If you are looking for a cheap film that'll make you laugh, cry and generally make you feel good, you can't go wrong! This could EASILY be the best animated film you've never seen!
